title: Part A
stimulusHtml:
1 point is earned for the proper setup using the ideal gas law and an answer that is consistent with the setup.

PV = nRT

PV RT =n= (1.04 atm)(1.00 L) (0.0821 L atm mol K )(1100 K) =0.0115  mol CO 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbdfwBIj xAHbqedmvETj2BSbqefm0B1jxALjhiov2DaebbnrfifHhDYfgasaac H8srps0lbbf9q8WrFfeuY=Hhbbf9v8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xbba9q8WqFf ea0=yr0RYxir=Jbba9q8aq0=yq=He9q8qqQ8frFve9Fve9Ff0dmeaa baqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaadaWcaaqaaiaadcfacaWGwb aabaGaamOuaiaadsfaaaGaeyypa0JaamOBaiabg2da9maalaaabaGa aiikaiaaigdacaGGUaGaaGimaiaaisdacaqGGaGaaeyyaiaabshaca qGTbGaaeykaiaabIcacaqGXaGaaeOlaiaabcdacaqGWaGaaeiiaiaa bYeacaqGPaaabaGaaiikaiaaicdacaGGUaGaaGimaiaaiIdacaaIYa GaaGymamaalaaabaGaaeitaiaabccacaqGHbGaaeiDaiaab2gaaeaa caqGTbGaae4BaiaabYgacaqGGaGaae4saaaacaGGPaGaaiikaiaaig dacaaIXaGaaGimaiaaicdacaqGGaGaae4saiaabMcaaaGaeyypa0Ja aGimaiaac6cacaaIWaGaaGymaiaaigdacaaI1aGaaeiiaiaab2gaca qGVbGaaeiBaiaabccacaqGdbGaae4tamaaBaaaleaacaaIYaaabeaa aaa@66EC@

title: Part B
stimulusHtml:
1 point is earned for disagreement with the claim and for a correct justification using stoichiometry or a discussion of the creation of an equilibrium condition.

Do not agree with claim

Explanation I: In experiment 1, the moles of CaCO3 = 50.0 g/100.09 g/mol = 0.500 mol CaCO3. If the reaction had gone to completion, 0.500 mol of CO2 would have been produced. From part (a) only 0.0115 mol was produced. Hence, the student's claim was false.

Explanation II: The two different experiments (one with 50.0 g of CaCO3 and one with 100.0 g of CaCO3) reached the same constant, final pressure of 1.04 atm. Since increasing the amount of reactant did not produce more product, there is no way that all of the CaCO3 reacted. Instead, an equilibrium condition has been achieved and there must be some solid CaCO3 in the container.

Explanation II: The two different experiments (one with 50.0 g of CaCO3 and one with 100.0 g of CaCO3) reached the same constant, final pressure of 1.04 atm. Since increasing the amount of reactant did not produce more product, there is no way that all of the CaCO3 reacted. Instead, an equilibrium condition has been achieved and there must be some solid CaCO3 in the container.

Do not agree with claim

Explanation I: In experiment 1, the moles of CaCO3 = 50.0 g/100.09 g/mol = 0.500 mol CaCO3. If the reaction had gone to completion, 0.500 mol of CO2 would have been produced. From part (a) only 0.0115 mol was produced. Hence, the student's claim was false.

Explanation II: The two different experiments (one with 50.0 g of CaCO3 and one with 100.0 g of CaCO3) reached the same constant, final pressure of 1.04 atm. Since increasing the amount of reactant did not produce more product, there is no way that all of the CaCO3 reacted. Instead, an equilibrium condition has been achieved and there must be some solid CaCO3 in the container.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml:
1 point is earned for the correct answer with justification.

The final pressure would be equal to 1.04 atm. Equilibrium was reached in both experiments; the equilibrium pressure at this temperature is 1.04 atm. As the reaction shifts toward the reactant, the amount of CO2(g) in the container will decrease until the pressure returns to 1.04 atm.

The final pressure would be equal to 1.04 atm. Equilibrium was reached in both experiments; the equilibrium pressure at this temperature is 1.04 atm. As the reaction shifts toward the reactant, the amount of CO2(g) in the container will decrease until the pressure returns to 1.04 atm.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml:
1 point is earned for correct explanation that is consistent with the student's answer to part (b).

Yes. For the equilibrium reaction represented by the chemical equation in this problem, at a given temperature the equilibrium pressure of CO2 determines the equilibrium constant. Since the measured pressure of CO2 is also the equilibrium pressure of CO2, K p = P C O 2 =1.04 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbdfwBIj xAHbqedmvETj2BSbqefm0B1jxALjhiov2DaebbnrfifHhDYfgasaac H8srps0lbbf9q8WrFfeuY=Hhbbf9v8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xbba9q8WqFf ea0=yr0RYxir=Jbba9q8aq0=yq=He9q8qqQ8frFve9Fve9Ff0dmeaa baqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaWGlbWaaSbaaSqaaiaadc haaeqaaOGaeyypa0JaamiuamaaBaaaleaacaWGdbGaam4tamaaBaaa meaacaaIYaaabeaaaSqabaGccqGH9aqpcaaIXaGaaiOlaiaaicdaca aI0aaaaa@3DC3@ .

Note: If the response in part (b) indicates "yes", that all of the CaCO3(s) had decomposed, then the point can be earned by stating that the system did not reach equilibrium in either experiment and hence the value of Kp cannot be calculated from the data.
